Or spending $200-$250 each person for bottle/table service, depending on how many are in your group.  It's a no brainer.

So back to the Tao restaurant....great environment good vibe, cool place to eat......average food.

ok I know I'm late to review this.. I ate here at the end of March, but one of my friends just reviewed it and it got me craving this place again. I loved it so much I HAVE to say something!! I'm sorry my review comes 2 months late! 

You walk into this place and it's just swanky and oozed coolness. I love the big Budda and the rest of the decor is funky as well. Loud ambient lounge/chill music could be heard overhead... I was so happy I was wearing a leopard print halter, otherwise I would have felt under dressed here. 

Cosmos were fantastic! The sushi was excellent too. I have no idea where they fly the sushi in - as we were in the dessert, but it didn't matter it tasted fabulous and fresh! Pan seared Tuna was fantastic, but OMG the  Miso Glazed Chilean Sea Bass was to DIE FOR- I mean to DIE FOR. I still dream about it 2 months later..... 

Bathrooms for me were confusing - the doors had a yin icon on one, and a yang on the other. I got to the door and though WTF, I should have kept up with my yoga class and maybe I would know this.... and while I was trying to decide which door I was going to bust through, some chick walked into Yin and I followed her. Later my friends nicely pointed out - had I not had 3 cosmos I might have noticed the female budda outside of the women's room as the clue... oooops who knew?

My take - this is a MUST visit place for dinner in Vegas. It will not disappoint, but make sure to make a reservation otherwise you will wait a long time! I made mine on open table a few weeks before my trip.

Absolutely BEAUTIFUL inside.   Statues, scented ponds filled with fresh rose petals, candles galore, dark, red, stone, Japanese calligraphy... gorgeous.     *gorgeous*...

HOWEVER.   The music and crowd on a Friday night was obnoxious as hell.   The food is great and our server was helpful, BUT only eat here if you like dining in a nightclub.  

Ridiculously loud, crowded and intense.   Not what I was hoping for.   I would only come back if it was lunchtime and the atmosphere was more serene.   

I don't mind going to nightclubs, I'm a professional dancer and I love a good cocktail, people watching et al...   I just don't wanna eat in the middle of one where I can't have a conversation without yelling.    

My dining companion had a splitting headache before we were done with our entree. 

Expect to be seated a full half hour late at least, even if you have a reservation.

I read that you still had to wait with reservations. I think we waited like 15 minutes past our reservation time.  We were entertained by some strong cocktails and a wandering saxophonists playing to the house beats the DJ was spinning. I tried to avert the saxophonist but homeboy just could not let up.

It is a beautiful restaurant. we were not thinking it would be a quiet romantic dinner. The husband and I did sharesies and had the spicy tuna tartare appetizer which looked like a roll, the rice had a crunch as if they put in on a frying pan...it was good.  Memorable was the wasabi crusted filet mignon with tempura onion rings. It had a little kick only wasabi would bring. Also memorable the crunchy spicy yellowtail roll with crushed onion rings. The lo mein with pork- ah okay...but you can get that anywhere i think. The lobster and shrimp dumplings were good.

Drinks were really good.  We enjoyed the people watching and the pulsing beats of the DJs. It's Vegas so don't expect bible study groups-it's all about the bachelors/bachelorettes and general party people. oh and ask for the stamp so you don't have to wait in the awful line

I don't what to make of this resturant.  This restaurant really did whored out East Asian culture with all the Buddhist figures, it almost seems ironic in the heart of Sin City.  This is another level of whorentialism by whites.

I really liked the decor. Fresh rose petals, buddhas, candlelights, dim, very romantic. We had the soft shell crab roll, shrimp tempura roll, and dragon roll with eels. They were all better than average, though a bit small - not unexpected.Kids wanted the lobster wonton soup and shrimp tempura. The soup was better than the tempura - too thick and oily. We tried the duck spring roll, it was pretty good, don't mind ordering again. The eight of us shared the kobe beef with scallons, XO shrimp,Pad thai,lo mein, kung pao chicken, assorted sashimi, and the lobster dish that I totally hate my friend for ordering .... just kidding about the hate part.....  Every entree was very salty, and the worst part was it tasted like the same sauce was used for every dish. with all the food we ordered and consumed, I actually still had room for dessert, I must say this is probably the best part of the meal. The chocolate parfait with Godiva liquer was nice, balances out the saltiness lingering in my mouth. Tried hubby's lychee sorbet - refreshing, kid's mousse fortune cookie, so-so, but they found it amusing. I actually could eat more, the portions were just too small. we did not see Paris Hilton, but did see Robin Leach with a couple young blonds. :)

This place made my night.

I must have gotten lucky because everything I ordered to eat was delicious (see my pics).  I shared the wasabi-encrusted filet mignon, sea-bass, fried rice, and salmon with udon noodles.  The rice wasn't anything special but each of the other dishes was delicious.  The sea-bass was amazingly cooked and the filet mignon hit the spot.

We had a group of 15 and the service was ultra-efficient and super smooth.  I'm a huge fan of the decor of Tao nightclub, and can say the same holds true with the design of the restaurant (tho it is a bit dark.)  

The servers were super friendly to us and at the end of the night as a perk for eating there, we got VIP stamps to get into the club.  And I'm not talking about "VIP" status where you get into a "VIP" line and wait another f-ing hour.  At 10PM we left the restaurant and were in the club in under 10 minutes even though a line was building up outside.  Considering I spent about $40 on the food, and entry into the club would have been about $20 anyways...well that's what I think anyone would call a good deal.

If you're going to come and complain about the "noise level" take a pause and think about it.  What do you expect from a resaurant sitting below the club (with the same name, mind you).

The only weird thing to me now is that two of my favorite places in Vegas have the same place ..Tao and Tao.  Nightclub and restaurant.

Ok, you walk in and the feeling is well, oh man, not this.  "House" music bumpin', I felt like I was in a scene from Showgirls - and not a sex scene.  I think Nomi Malone would throw a hissy fit and throw fries all over the pretentious jerks who strut around at "Tao".  The 30 foot tall Buddha is striking - and stupid.  I had tuna nigiri (which was really good) chicken something on a stick, some sort of fried affair and a whole bunch of other fusion food.  The food was ok but it made me crave real food, that's something about Vegas I noticed.  Yeah, they make a good mojito with a cute little sugar cane stick up in it, it was sweet, it made feel good, just like the feeling I had when I got out of there.

This was the unsuccessful leg one of our ultimately successful bid to find hella late night night sushi in Vegas on a Monday night near the strip.  The decor is beautiful and the host guy was very polite in telling us where to find more info... from Social House in TI.

I heard Tao was great...well as Pooh might say, "Tao just is."

In turn, I would say it was bunk. Food was just ok.(Fried and lukewarm) Service was decent. Maître'd was waaaaaay too into himself, seriously brah...

Can't recommend Tao to my fellow Yelpers.

Went here with some friends for dinner.  It's a nice fusion spot and the food is tasty and has a good variety.  It's expensive and our waiter said a lot of VIP's show up there.  It was convienent for us because we were staying in the Venetian.  I'd go back.  They have some crazy drinks.

Well after some ups and downs in Vegas dining i'm glad to have stumbled upon Tao.
All because I was anxious to get out of the Venetian for a new setting, to my surprise before I could exit the rose petals and candlelight tubs caught my eye!
nice setting, but thats Vegas for you
Sat at the bar as I was taking a shopping break
Dean guided me towards the sea bass on the small plate menu.
For five bites a bit costly (17), but worth every penny!
My only gripe with him would be that he didn't suggest the dinner portion knowing how good it was. One spicy tuna roll order later I was where I needed to be, but sad to know I would be leaving Vegas and not to eat this "delish" dish again.
Oh and he was somewhat attentive, but could of checked up an additional time or two to make it perfect.

Tao... great ambiance! Love the dim lighting, bathtubs filled with rose petals, candles and especially the huge Buddha statue as the focal point of the restaurant/club. 

With that said... the food... eehh. Yes, just eeh. I had great service - the wait staff was very attentive - my water glass was always topped off even thought it was 3/4s full.

Maybe it was the hype of everyone - family, friends, celebrities - that I thought my dinner at TAO was going to be a culinary experience. Honestly, I probably would have had a better meal at PF Chang's and spent a lot less for it. My appetizer (steamed dumplings) was bland and my noodle dish was so oily and greasy! I left feeling quite unsatisfied and quite queasy too. 

Would I go TAO for the club and drinks? Sure - it's the Buddha that calls me.

Would I go for dinner at TAO again? Yes, but only if I was outnumbered in a large group and that's where everyone decided to go. Otherwise... probably not.

Atmosphere is very lounge-y, decor is really cool.  The food was alright.  I did like the chilean sea bass satay.  But 2 pieces for $17 is crazy.  I don't think it was enough food, and I'm a small eater.  

The waiter talked to us like we didn't know how to read a menu.  Hence, I thought the experience was ok.

to be honest, i actually loved this asian fusion restaurant. and normally, i'm not down with places where there's more caucasian people than asians. but tao is totally an exception. our party of 14 had reservations at 8:15 on a saturday night, and we got seated exactly at 8:15 (give or take a couple minutes). we had to get 2 tables, but our waitress was fabulous! she was sooo nice, i was expecting her to be sort of snobby because well, it's tao. i ordered the xo shrimp with rice and long beans (beware, some items don't include sides such as rice and veggies. ask the waitress/waiter which ones do). it was FANTASTIC. the shrimp was perfectly cooked, and the beans were so tasty. the rice was also cooked well, something i didn't expect, since it's so americanized at tao. boyfriend ordered the salmon with udon noodles. holy cow! i wish i'd ordered that, too! (not instead, but TOO!). luckily, he always has a small appetite, so we got to share!  perfectly cooked salmon, too. not dry at all, or bland. from what my brother said, the shabu shabu was also really yummy, and the broth that it's cooked in is nicely flavored.

not only was the food great, the service was incredible. people kept asking us if we were enjoying ourselves, and our waitress and waiter were not rude one bit, which made my cousin's 30th birthday so special for her. they recommended the dessert sampler, $65 for a variety of desserts (a HUGE fortune cookie, chocolate mousses, molten lava cake) and they stuck a sparkler in there so we can sing happy birthday to her. she loved it! and it fed all 14 of us. the desserts are fabulous! our party spent $845 a good amount of food, a couple bottles of sake, and a bottle of wine. not bad at all, in my opinion. i will for sure be there the next time i'm in vegas!

Okay, so this place is really hyped up .... but it didn't fall short.  Really, the food is excellent -- the service pretty good -- the ambiance is exactly what you'd want or expect it to be.  They actually kept our reservation pretty close to the time we made it for.  So, the experience was a great one!  

My party of eight got a varied mix of food but I had the filet mignon udon noodles and I have to say, they were pretty damn good.  Surprisingly good.  :-) I came out feeling very satisfied -- and so did my entire party.  

I really want to find out where that picture of the older asian man smoking the opium pipe can be found ... it was really beautiful.  Anyway, enjoy Tao folks.  :-)

I had realllllly high hopes for my dining experience at Tao, and to be honest, it was way below my expectations!

We arrived slightly early for our reservations but were seated immediately, which was great. The atmosphere was awesome. So trendy, cool, interesting lighting, and how can you miss the HUGE buddah statue in the middle of it all? Undeniably, the atmosphere is the best part of Tao. 

To drink, I had the Lychee Nut Martini. Very, very good. Strong flavor of alcohol and lychee alike, it was one of the best drinks I had on my trip. 

We started out with Lobster Wontons in a Shiitake Ginger Broth. By far, the best thing we ate all evening, although the $18 price tag was a little hefty for four bite-sized wontons. Yes, they were delicious- plump, filled entirely with chunks of lobster, but still. I am a huge ginger and mushroom fan, so this broth was awesome! I wish I had some rice to sop up the goodness once we were through with the dumplings!

Maybe this is where we went wrong. We decided to get sushi and split it. Maybe one shouldn't order sushi from Tao, as everyone around us seemed to be thoroughly enjoying their food. Plus, it looked better than ours. 

Shrimp Tempura Roll- This was very unique because it was served with curry sauce. I  enjoyed the flavor of the curry with the sushi roll. Almost like a fusion of Indian/Japanese cuisine. 

Spicy Tuna Roll- Good, but nothing amazing. I've had just as good a Spicy Tuna Roll at a hole in the wall for half the price. I did NOT like that it was served atop a puddle of mayonnaise. I understand that mayonnaise is blended within the roll as a 'spicy sauce', but this was just WAY too much mayo. Yuck. 

Alaskan Salmon, Crab, and Avocado Roll- Nothing really identifiable or special. Once again, I've had MUCH better. 

Perhaps my expectations were too high, but Tao felt like an upscale PF Changs. However, I'm glad I went because I've wanted to dine there forever. If I were to do it over, I would order one of their entrees, like Mongolian Scallion Chicken, Miso Glazed Chilean Sea Bass, or Braised Spicy Shrimp. 

Service was not very good. Felt like we were rushed the entire time.

The server was amazing!  Through out the meal his was very helpful and friendly....... but that doesn't make up for the awful food!   Ambiance doesn't make up for the disgusting food.  The food is so bad....... it makes it over priced.  

We started off with veggie dumplings.  Let me just say, Trader Joe's makes better dumplings!  The we got an tuna wasabi appetizer.  The pieces were so big, we could barely fit them in our mouth!  We also got another roll that was cut into large pieces.

It comes down to this, I don't mind spend money on a good meal!  What a waste of money!

Don't go!!!!!!

I went with my boyfriend & 4 yr old son & we really enjoyed it. Service was friendly, attentive & majority of the waiters were quite decent looking lol.

*Lychee Martini - Excellent
*Pork Spring Roll w/ Thai Chili sauce - delicioius, tho they're more like a triangle shape than a roll lol
*Pad Thai - mediocre, wouldn't order it again
*Crunchy Spicy Yellowtail Roll w/ Crushed Onion Rings - Flavorful, Fresh & unique
*a Crusted Red Snapper dish - Awesome. the fish was cooked just right: not too dry, not too undercooked.& the sauce went well with it. 

It's a fun, trendy atmosphere & I definitely want to go back...minus one star for the small portions...but ya gotta expect it in Vegas I guess.

After watching an insanely trippy show by Elton John at Caesar's palace (I swear I needed drugs to fully appreciate that show)me, my sister, my cousins and their friends headed over Tao for a late (and I mean LATE - it was a 10:45pm reservation!) dinner. I was little bit skeptical about going to eat at this place.  First off, I'm from San Francisco - it's hard to top the taste of Bay Area Asian foods that sell for a cheaper rate than Tao, and 2nd - it was ridiculously loud because Tao night club is right above the restaurant.  We had a reservation and still had to wait about 30 minutes.  Fine... I got that it was busy.  But after not having dinner, and being a little loopy after the Elton John show - I wasn't a very happy camper and I wanted to bail.

But the dinner was for a birthday and I didn't want to disappoint by being a Crabby Patty.  So I dealt with it.

Since we were a large group of 10, we were seated in a nice little alcove in the very back of the restaurant.  It was nice and cozy and I felt at ease.  Thank heavens we weren't in the middle of the restaurant where it was crowded. I was crabby enough as it was to have to deal with the lack of space.  

We had a nice view of Mike Tyson as he sat at the table behind us with a lovely female friend.  We tried to be slick in taking pictures of him as each one of us placed our order.

When the food came out, I wasn't so impressed by the presentation but I figured I shouldn't judge by looks alone.  I ordered the Chicken Yellow Curry.  The smell was heavenly. I saw the little pieces of lemongrass in it. That was different for me. I've never had Chicken Yellow Curry with lemongrass. I poured some curry on my rice and took a spoonful... it was fantastic that I had to offer some over to everyone else for a taste.  The chicken potstickers on the table tasted fresh and succulent.  My sister had a beef dish that was just DIVINE.  But my favorite was the dish I ordered.  And today I still crave for that wonderful burst of flavor on my tongue.  As I always say... "Party in my mouth...heeeeyyyyy!!!"

This restaurant had it all. A very hip vibe, cool decor (For SF Yelpers it reminded me of Ana Mandara), GREAT service and really good food. Honestly, the service is what took this place to a 5 for me. Our waiter was named Zeban (?) and he was really helpful on suggesting dishes and pacing our food. He even held back on the last order (Some Spring rolls) until we were sure we wanted them. He was right. it was one too many dishes. Here are a few highlights- Lobster Won tons were great. BBQ pork was so so as was the Sliced Steak. Crispy Tuna Tartare Sushi was amazing, as was the Sea Bass Satay. The Udon noodles with BBQ Salmon was cooked to perfection, but I was expecting a Soup type Udon and this was a large piece of Salmon next to a pile of noodles. The star of the night was the Peking Duck served MuShu style. Wine list was good and wine service was very good. I liked that Zeban knew his stuff. Nothing worse than a waiter that has no clue what the wines taste like. The sake list was really great too,. We had the giant Fortune Cookie for dessert, which was a kick. It was a super fresh fortune cookie filled with white and chocolate mousse, and served with fresh fruit. Yum.It came with 4 fortunes in it, which was a fun way to end dinner. 
Finally, a warning: Yin= Ladies Room and Yang = Men's Room. 2 men walked into the ladies while we were in there. The restroom attendant (love that touch, so old school) said it happens all the time...

Since we were staying at the Venetian, we chose Tao for our dinner destination the last night of our Vegas weekend... My dad made the reservation in advance and let them know we were celebrating a birthday.  There were six of us in the party, and we actually all arrived right on time!  The hostess said it would be a few minutes, so we sat at a table in the lounge area, ordered some drinks, and snacked on some of the wasabi peas.  The waitress that took our cocktail orders was sweet, and she made some great Taojitos for the group!  At 8:30, we were wondering why we had to wait so long and getting a bit ansy... we finally were taken to our table around 8:40.

Dinner was amazing once we were seated.  Chris was our server and took great care of us.  We enjoyed a round of appetizers including lobster dumplings, crispy tuna tataki, edamame, duck spring rolls, and eggplant tempura.  We also did dinner family style and shared wasabi steak, pad thai with shrimp, crispy snapper, seafood in black bean sauce, spicy eggplant, curry shrimp tempura maki, and pork fired rice.  It's two days later, and I am writing this all from memory - it was that good!  (Usually I would have to look back at the menu to remember what we ordered, but it all made a lasting impression in this case).  We literally cleaned all of the plates - everything was great, and quick too!

Luckily, even with all of that food, we saved room for dessert.  Chris brought out a beautiful birthday cake for the birthday girl and boy (my bro and sis are twins).  I'm talking really quality, beautiful gourmet cake (like AJ's in AZ).  It had "Happy Birthday A & Z" written on it in chocolate and it was a vanilla layer cake of sorts.  

I didn't pay the bill, and I'm sure it was expensive, but this was by far the best meal we had on the trip, and I'm sure it was worth it!  The only reason I'm giving 4 stars instead of 5 is because of the wait we had upon arrival - other than that, Tao was amazing!  Beautiful ambiance too - I'll have to go back next time to check out the nightclub!

I gues after here too many times, I'm tired of it.  the only think i ever order is the black cod! expensive....portions are alright! Trendy thats for sure! I love the bathrooms! Its kinda fun to put ur hand underneath and shake a guys hand! haha!
Tao is is indeed delish. I particularly enjoyed the Kobe beef that you cook yourself in a ginger scallion broth. The decor is fantastic and true to Vegas style, the music is hot!

3.5 stars. I ordered the Peking Duck spring rolls as my appetizer and fried red snapper as my main course (snapper was the stand out). This restaurant is massive! A friend of mine at dinner exclaimed that this place looked exactly like PF Changs (they're like an Americanize chinese food place with nicer decor and an american wait-staff). It was a replica of that place, just this one was the super-walmart of PF Changs'. 

The peking duck rolls tasted like they were from a pre-packaged roll set they also lack a sizable amount of hoisin dipping sauce which I was looking forward to. I was underwhelmed since they were $14. The red snapper was actually good, I enjoyed and recommend it.

The music was pretty loud in the place, so I wouldn't bring my family here for a quiet meal.

Overall, decent, not memorial except for the semi-naked girls in the bathtubs as we left the restaurant. This is vegas, what do you expect?

4 stars for ambiance and food despite the /extremely/ generic "asian" decor.

I had the filet mignon shabu-shabu, which I think was the first time I've had shabu-shabu, and it was delicious.  I sort of knew what to expect so I wasn't surprised when the waiter brought out a cast iron pot and sterno can, but the meat was really exceptional.  The appetizers I sampled were decent and the waiter made a good sake suggestion for the table.

The ambiance in this place is set when you walk in through a short, arched hallway lined on each side with 5 stone bathtubs, each half-full with water and covered in floating rose pedals with a single candle in the middle.  The main dining room, dimly lit, is laid out around a towering (i mean 20-30 ft) Buddha.  If you can imagine, *from there* it gets a little cheesy.  The photographs on the walls range from sumo wrestlers to tibetan monks to little old chinese ladies and beyond.

The music was a little loud but they had a live drummer playing an amplified hand drum to the DJ's electronica.  It was actually decent music.

We came with a party of 9; we ate like crazy and drank like crazy and the bill was under 600. Not bad at all.

Service was great took a bit to get the bill but, that was the only complaint we had. I was very impressed with ambiance and the amount of people working there. Drinks never got low and there was always someone right at our table in all black checking in on us. Food was delish and the sake was AMAZING! If you are looking for a great dinner in Las Vegas I highly recommend. If you are a large party be aware even for a massive restaurant they only have a limited amount of tables that can accommodate a party of 8. 

Enjoy! (photos loaded of yummy sake)

Dined at this restaurant one night this week with the crew.  Exotic ambience, cool Asian decors, friendly staff, nice lighting mix, excellent food and drink selections .  Their sushi selections are excellent - we tried it along with some Sake.  This place is high in my list for dining, & clubbing as well.

Friggin awesome...So what do you do when you are over buffet's and eating junk in Vegas? You eat at one of the "FINE" dining establishments in your hotel. And when they mean fine they mean FINE! This place is awesome and also gets you front of line status if you want to go to Tao nightclub.

Since we had such a large party (8) we couldn't get a reservation until 1045. A little late for dinner....but its Vegas....I woke up at 5PM so it's not that late ;-)

We were seated and our server was very helpful in explaining the menu and the items on it and mentioning the special of the night. 

So I had the 8oz wasabi encrusted filet mignon. BEST STEAK ever!!! I have eaten at most of the "Fine" steak houses in San Diego and one other steak house in Vegas but this one takes the cake. It was so tender and beautifully cooked (medium rare). My friends also had the special of the night (a 12oz Rib Eye) this was also very good and cooked perfectly. We also had the beef shabu shabu pot....it was good but I wish we could have tried the kobe beef...that would have been awesome. Either way I could have eaten the broth by itself. The other thing that stood out was the kobe beef carpaccio. EXCELLENT!! Marinated and cut exquisitely.

All in all the best restaurant I have eaten at so far in my 27 years.

Another successful transplant from NYC, this place is great.  Spendy, trendy, and a little confusing menu wise if you have a big group like we did.  we had a great waiter that helped us with our order and nobody left disappointed or un-full.  The place is loud and full of energy and beautiful people.

Ask for help with the menu if theres a group.  If youre a couple youre golden.  So many things to try, you could eat here 100 times.

No complaints at all.

Different,trendy  Certainly Asian fusion.  Reminded me more of the Buddha Bar in Dubai. Great Ambience. Food was good . Sushi is great.  Got to get used to reservations, else expect long waits for dinner

I want the girls in rose petal bathtubs...wahh!

Four stars because I didn't get to see the girls in the bathtubs.  Shoulda gone on a weekend night.

Food was great.   Korean BBQ pork chops, Peking duck, ribs, sushi, dumplings, egg rolls, sake, all done in a very upscale way.
One thing that I really liked was the Chef's Special option with the sushi.  This is where you tell the waiter how much you want to spend in sushi and the chef will come up with something to impress you.  I like the idea of challenging a chef to give his best rather than just fill an order.  I wish I could remember the two rolls that were exceptional, but will maybe update this review later.

The decor is amazing, decorated in classy asian theme with a giant buddha in the restauarant.  They could maybe get rid of the sumo wrestler photos.  The staff was attentive to our every need.  

This place is not for the cheap.  We spent about $500 for five people.  

I want the girls in rose petal bathtubs...wahh!

Dafe

Loved the food here. Chilean seabass was to die for! This place was soo good I went back there the second night in LV! I ordered the NY steak and it was equally good. The steak is nicely sliced up for you, i.e. ez to eat. Loved the asian fusion sauce they drizzled over it with a bed of shitake mushrooms. Mmmhhmmm.
Wish there was a TAO here in SF... /sigh.

Other than the fact that I fell asleep at the dinner table at Tao (we won't get into that now), i have nothing but good things to say about the place! 

The food is amazing. Everything on the menu is delectable and I make sure that everytime I come to Vegas (which is actually pretty often) I always come here, and order something new. The drinks are so superly tasty - it makes you not want to stop (and that's the beginning of falling asleep at dinner).

so impressed. i really was hesitant to believe all the hype about tao, but all of it is well-deserved. the staff is unbelievably friendly and SO good looking. being hot is undoubtedly a prerequisite to apply for a job at tao. i was with a party of six and we had reservations for 7:30. we didn't actually make it to our table until around 8:00 or so but i absolutely didn't mind. the lounge area is gorgeous and believe me, you will enjoy sipping on cocktails and people watching... so much that you MIGHT not even want to go to your table : )

try the tao-tini. so yummy.

for appetizers, we had the vegetarian spring rolls with chili sauce and the pork dumplings - both delicious.

as an entree, i had the salmon, though i'm not sure of it's exact title on the menu, it's the only salmon dish there. try it, i promise you will not be disappointed.

also, don't be mislead into thinking tao is too pricey for you. everything on the menu is moderately priced and well worth it.

only downside - it seems as if bussers try to get you out and turn over tables as soon as possible, trying to pick up your dish before your even done with it. small price to pay, though, for such a great dinner.

I totally get it.  The promoters/owners lure you into Tao Restaurant, ply you with yummy food and drink, and then convince you that Tao Nightclub is just as upscale and well-done.  Don't fall for it!  Just eat the food, drink the booze, and leave!  You'll have a better night for it.

Tao Restaurant is amazing.  I loved the decor, the service, the short wait, and of course the food.  This behemoth of a restaurant does Asian fusion right.  I had the Tao-tini (after my requisite dirty Grey Goose on the rocks).  Fruity, strong as all hell, and delicious.  My PIC and I started with the lobster wontons.  Best.  Dish.  Ever.  Next time I go back, that's all I'm ordering.  We also had the lobster dumplings to start.  Good.  But definitely not the lobster wontons.

We then ordered the Thai fish hot pot, which had a very strong sauce, overpowering on its own, but perfect with steamed rice.  We made the mistake of ordering veggie fried brown rice.  Why were we trying to be healthy? Anyway, what came was a plate of veggies + mush.  Ugh.  Panda Express makes a better fried rice than that!

Upon leaving the Venetian, my PIC and I decided that next time, we're just ordering 6 servings of the lobster wontons.  And then heading to Jet to shake it all off!

P.S.  One of my students told me that her group of friends was offered free dinner + drinks + Tao admission the same weekend.  So if you have a group of 10+ cute Asian girls, you may get dinner for free!  Otherwise, expect to spend about $50/person, not including drinks.

First of all my favorite thing to do in Vegas is eat. Tao makes no exception to please. First course Lobster Wontons, super delish and Sashimi Lobe Beef just melted in your mouth. All the entrees we shared were amazing, cocktails superb. The decor was great but to be expected from all over the top Vegas restaurants. I only wish there was one in Chicago.

It's pretty unfair to not seperate my reviews but I'm going to make this a resturant/lounge combo. 

Don't go there thinking that it will be anything like the location in NY ( which is a hometown fav) the Las Vegas version has an identity all of its own. I did the sushi platter with the chef's selection. Your better off sticking close to the sushi chef's for an entertaining night. 

Personally I suggest bringing a crowd that can appreciate a place like Tao. The whole enviroment inspires intelligent conversation and anything less seems to put a damper on the whole experiance. 

Even though I was a guest of Rich they STILL made me get a line pass and re enter just to go upstairs. I hear they make ppl pay to get in but they just let us walk up. Upstairs is cool. Naked women decorating the place is a perk. 

Not a place to get your dance on .....stick to the bar behind the wierd skully wall.

Good place for groups since it's dark, trendy music, and colorful drinks.  Not so much for a romantic night.  

I've been to Tao New York few years ago and was not so impressed by fancy expensive Chinese food.  It was just a place that I can say "Yeah, I've been there" and not return again.  Somehow I found myself here in the deviation also known as Las Vegas' version.  The best way I can describe Las Vegas spun versions restaurants (ie Mesa Grill, Delmonico, David Burke, Koi, etc etc) is large productions, lacking heart and character in its food.  Mass production?

We ordered the miso glazed salmon which was fine, the size of the fish was beyond my expectations (insert my mass production epiphany), spicy toro tartar on crispy rice.... a nice attempt at copying Koi's signature dish but fell short on the crispy rice, it was too thick so the crispyness did not stick together but fell all over my plate.... some Filet Mignon yaki udon dish that really made me miss Oh! Taisho's kimchi yakiudon but I digress.

It was a very bland dining experience.  The only good thing - we were able to receive comps to Tao Nightclub.

A group of my friends and I went to Tao last night to celebrate a birthday dinner for eight.  The service was absolutely horrible. I made a reservation several weeks ago for 8 pm and they made us wait for 45 minutes.  Once we got seated, it took another 20 minutes for them to take our order then we waited another 20 mintues between appetizer and the main courses.  When my friend complained, the waitress responded by saying, "I was trying to time it right," then proceeded to bring out the rest of the remaining dishes (all six of them) in one shot!  

Gratuity for a large group is automatically  added at 20%, so I got the impression that  they take no pride in taking care of their guests once you're seated.

My rankings are the following: 
Service: one star
Food: two 1/2 stars

The Chilean Sea Bass and the New York Strip steak were decent.  The potstickers were average.  The noodles and the XO string beans were over seasoned and soggy.  You can get better Chinese food elsewhere for 1/4 the price. We paid $57 per person.

Bottom line is you pay for the ambiance mostly at Tao, but the food is mediocre at best.  A dinner that should have taken 1 hour and 1/2, took 3 hours due to poor service and lack of attention.  I would think a restaurant of their caliber would take more pride in treating their guests right.

I love the Tao in Vegas, more so then the 1 in nyc..  I like the vibe, the atmosphere, the music and the drinks. The Bartenders are fun and friendly also..  And the food I am in love with the Lobster Wontons in the Ginger Broth that is pretty much all I eat every time I come here..   Its like having an orgasm in my mouth, when I eat them I make these moans and groans and not a lot of food does that for me, so because of that I must go to Tao every time when in Vegas cause its reliable and I don't have to fake it.. ; )~

Was here celebrating my 30th Birthday. It was way too loud and crowded, even for a Wednesday! The music was pumpin', and it just was too loud during dinner. For a club, yes fine, but I didnt like dining like that.
The service was great, and the food was all good. Had some sushi, then Pad Thai. My husband had a fried rice meal. I also got a special birthday mousse filled fortune cookie! Was really cute :)
I probably wouldn't return to eat here...

Really tasty, filling food. Almost too filling, though. I could only stuff down half of my food before they carted it away. Came on a Saturday night, so of course it was super loud and crowded. Good service, but we didn't have the same waiter twice. Is that weird? I thought it was weird.
I would come here again when it's not a busy meal hour, and would be sure to be super hungry. Nothing's sadder than seeing a delicious coconut chicken curry being scooted off because you can't finish it. And don't even think about asking for the rest to go, lest you like public humiliation. 
Spendier than some... there was 1 beer, a glass of wine, 1 potsticker appetizer, curry and pad thai, which ended up being a little more than $100. But eh, it's Vegas, what do you expect.
I had fun when i went to this club last year!  Didn't have to wait in line at all.... fun times!

I do not have enough good things to say about this place! We were staying at the Venetian and wanted to go to the nightclub afterwards so we figured we'd just have dinner here.

The service at this place is impeccable! Not only was our server completely attentive, but there was also a clean up person waiting on his toes. Did you ever play Roller Coaster Tycoon when you were younger? Well, if not- in the game there are custodial workers that you can pick up and move over to any mess you see so they can clean it up right away. This is pretty much what that guy was. I swear there must be some one overlooking the tables at all times so if any spills occured, they "pick" this guy up and drop him at our table with wash cloth in hand, ready to clean up. Oh and upon realizing that I had received the pad thai with chicken instead of shrimp, I informed our server who apologized and offered to get it replaced immediately. After declining, mere moments later someone in management stopped by to apologize and offered the correct dish for me to take home- free of charge. If we weren't going clubbing right after I would have gladly accepted because that would have made for some awesome drunken munchies.

That leads me to the next thing. The food was delicious. Everyone at my table loved their meal. Also the general ambiance of the restaurant was nice. We were sitting there talking about how it really doesn't get much better: good food, good company, good wine. What a meal! My only complaint is that it is a little bit dark and loud in there. Hard to hear/see people.

Oh! Side note.  Upon being seated, we informed our server that we wanted to go to Tao the nightclub afterwards (we had heard that they can help you get in for free). Someone was sent to our table near the end of the meal to help us out. Unfortunately they could only give us a "line jump" stamp but it didn't really matter since we were staying at the Venetian and were already on the guest list.

OK, I know I'm supposed to be critical of Tao - but I really enjoyed my meal there the other night. The food was flavorful and very good. I went with a very large group and they sat us in a separate space from the rest of the dining area. That allowed the wait staff to focus on our party - and they were great (in the past I've found the wait staff to be very rushed). We had a set menu with a good mix of food. Highlight for me was the cod. Sushi was OK too (just). When we left I was amazed to see the lines of people trying to get into the nightclub (very different than the crowd at dinner). Overall a great place to go especially if you're already staying at or near the Venetian. Was surprisingly better than I expected.

I really want to love Tao. I love the 30ft Buddha. I love Tao in NYC.  But Tao Vegas... ughh.  Get your crap together. 

You get 2 stars because the food is still good.  The drinks are good, especially the Mango Tamarind Martini.  The Giant Fortune Cookie is one of my favorite desserts.  
 
Our reservation was for a Sunday night, 8:15PM, the restaurant wasn't even packed, and there was no one in the bar, we showed up on time, and were told our table was just about ready.  Yet we waited almost an hour for our table!  We almost bailed then, but we were really hungry and Asian food sounded good. 

You've crammed too many tables on the floor near the Buddha.  Our table was so close to the other tables, that some of us had to get out of our seats to let the servers by. 

Your servers suck, wait, correction, our server Heimer sucked.  We were charged about $40 worth of drinks we did not order.  We had a party of 7, yet we were charged for 8 sodas.  Only two people had a coke, without being offered a refill.  We had some bottles of Corona on our tab.  Corona?  Do people even drink Corona after the age of 18???

Our server acted like he was doing us a favor by taking our order.  He was extremely rude and really, there are so many other restaurants I would love to dine at during a weekend in Vegas.  I will never waste my time going to Tao LV again.

Wow...Tao is like a P.F. Chang's with mediocre food, clueless bartenders and pounding music.  The business model is sad really, they created a gorgeous space, disregarded all other details and then watched the tourists flow in...

Lisa:  this place is totally not worth the price tag.  we ordered 4 appetizers, four entrees, and one dessert for about 90 per person.  if the food was good, i wouldnt mind, but it was simple overpriced mediocre food.  meat  and fish was dry and flavorless.  the only this that was good was the kobe tartar and the hotpot soup.  dessert was nothing special.  they blended their nightclub and restaurant together, so it was super crowded and we couldnt distinguish the line for the club and restaurant.  the super loud techno music made it extremely hard to hear our waitress.  presentations were nice and the restaurant itself was really pretty.  you're basically just paying for the view

Tao just flat out lacks what makes a great restaurant.  

Waiter = Davy

SERVICE - The WORSE part of Tao is their service.  It is very very obvious that their waiters want to squeeze as much money out of you as possible.  I understand that people need to make money & waiters want you to order more. Go ahead and make that money, But there has to be a balance that waiters don't cross or else it will be TOO obvious & the customer will give you a 10% tip of the slightly bigger check instead of the 20% they were planning to give if the guy acted like what he was suppose to be, a good waiter.  
When we sat down, we were offered 2 choices of water, both of which they charge for.  The option of bottled water is normal for "high class" restaurants everywhere, but it's the a-hole way of wording & tone that pisses you off.  My group of 6 didn't care for the bottled water because we were all ordering cocktails & beers anyways.  So we said "Just normal tab water is fine".  A BIG frown on Davy's face, and raises his voice in a mocking tone & says "In Las Vegas, no one will give you tab water."  HAHA, a big freakin joke or what?  Couple of us in the group comes to vegas about 5 times a yr for business with the company.  We've been to more than a few trendy restaurants in the 5 star properties.  We went to Shibuya at MGM just 2 nights before, we had a CHOICE of bottled or tab. 

DÉCOR - If you've been to trendy restaurants in LA or NY, there is nothing special about this place.  Don't get pulled in by the hype that the promoters try to put onto the place.  

FOOD - Onto the food selection, Davy tells us "Its my job to explain the menu to you and I'll be HONEST with you, these are my favorites" & proceeds to point out the 2 most expensive items on each section of the menu.  As he was doing that, we were just looking at each other like ... look at this clown.  We ordered what we wanted ourselves, again Davy's service starts getting worse.  All the food were very normal, nothing bad, nothing special.

CHECK - When we were done, Davy comes over & said "You guys have to get desert, everybody's doing it" What a pathetic half joke half pressure line.  We passed on it.  When he brings the check, we find that its more than what it was suppose to be.  On a closer look, he charged us for the price of entrees for 2 orders when we ordered appetizers.  Davy insisted that he gave us the entrees which we wouldn't know because the portions were all small.  Even if he did, it was his mistake when he took the order as we honestly all heard our friends order the appetizer.  Again, crooks.  

There are PLENTY of nice trendy restaurant/club in Vegas, try any of those.  Don't be sucker & go because of the "hype" like we did.

The food was fantastic, and I highly recommend the chef's tasting sampler. The highlights were the peking duck roll, kobe beef, citrus japanese snapper and the dumplings. For drinks, I had the Tao-hito, which unfortunately just tasted watered down. Also, the decor is well done, as has been mentioned before, the 30-foot Buddha wall is sweet. The service was great once the food started coming, but previous to that it was slow and it took some time to get our drinks. Lastly, if you go with a group, you may want to limit it to six people only because we had to cram in eight sizable guys around a table designed for six. There were other tables which would've worked, but the majority seemed setup for six.

I would never compare this place to PF Chang's. Do you see a puddle of grease or a pile of salt? Nope. 

You must understand first that I have a serious problem when it comes to chocolate lava cake. All those kids down $1k at the poker tables got nothing on me and my lava cake. 6 months ago, I came to Tao for dinner and was the only one who wanted to get dessert (surprise, surprise). I ordered the lava cake for MYSELF because no one would split with me but I left for 15 min to pick up my friend from the hotel lobby and when I returned, the cake was GONE. Everything from the chocolate chopsticks to the ice cream and every drop of chocolate was G-O-N-E!!! My friends remind me as much as possible how delicious this cake was, and I've wondered about it ever since.

It's my last day in Vegas and I had yet to get my precious chocolate cake. After gorging myself on pounds of bacon wrapped fillet mignon and queso bread at a Brazilian Steakhouse, with just 20 min to make it to the Bellagio to see "O," I called my order in and rushed over to Tao to pick up my precious lava cake. Gimme a break, it was my last chance!

I got dropped off at the lobby and ran in to pick up my order, but when I looked in the bag I noticed they didn't have plastic forks. What?! I guess I'm probably the only one who has ever ordered something to go, so I sat down at the bar to take just one bite. Yum... (No I did not use my hands). 

My friend went to the bathroom so I decided to continue eating while I waited. So I'm sitting at the bar by myself eating chocolate cake out of a plastic box, with chocolate on my face, and 10 bartenders gawking at me.

Me: (Gorging myself with chocolate cake)
Bartender: Would you like a...uh... glass of water?
Me: *om nom nom* no thanks *nom nom*

By the time my friend was back from the bathroom, the box was empty. Needless to say, after hearing me rave about getting this chocolate cake all weekend long, my friends who waited in the car, were shocked when I came back empty handed. 

I can't say I remember exactly how the cake tasted because I wolfed it down so fast, but I do remember the taste of victory, and it was glorious.

This review is for both the restaurant and nightclub.

Yum!

We had a large group (12 of us).  Server started off all right, suggesting we order family style (which we were going to do anyway), and asking who wanted to be in charge of ordering.  After that though, he got pretty pushy, with all his recommendations corresponding directly to the most expensive items on the menu.  I get that you make money off of tips, and that you're getting an automatic 20% off our large party, but really?  If you give me a good service, I'll tip above and beyond the 20% you talk on automatically.  Guy was a bit clueless too, when someone mentioned we were Korean, he was wondering if there was anything Korean inspired on the menu . . . either the staff isn't trained well, or he's just bad.  The food is Asian fusion, with strong Chinese influences, and a bit of Japanese and Thai thrown in.

Anyway, the food was okay - the prawns were over-cooked, but the beef was good, and the eggplant was delicious.  Edamame was good, but that's hard to screw up.  On the other hand, the prices were exorbitant for the quality and small portion sizes.

With as many options as there are in Vegas, I don't see myself returning on any future trips . . .

I'm surprised by the number of low ratings for this place.  It's pretty difficult getting reservations at Tao less than a couple of days in advance, unless you're fine eating at 9:45.  But for those not staying at the Venetian and want to go to Tao club afterward, dining there will get you a vip pass to skip the long lines.

Now the food part. The lobster wontons were AMAZING.  I know it sounds odd, but every bite was like a taste of lobster heaven.  The sauce concoction was just incredibly delicious. I also had curry chicken and sirloin steak (forgot the correct entree names), which were good but not great. I guess without the lobster wontons, I'd give Tao a 3 star.

I never got to even eat here. but i am reviewing their service.

yeah this place may be swanky, but their service is unimaginably rude.

my party had a reservation for 9:30 pm. we got there at 9:20 pm and they made us wait until 9:50 - 10:00. yes i understand a big party is hard to seat. yes i understand that people don't want to leave. but a reservation is a reservation. if you arent going to stay true to it, then don't take our credit card numbers and don't act like you remember us. because you forgot about my party 20-30 mins after the reservation.

another thing. while waiting, there was nowhere to wait properly. we kept getting shooed away.

they also threatened to charge us for leaving after we waited 40 mins.... can i say illegal?

i wouldn't say don't go here. but be hella careful when you do. rude. but the place was nice!

Waited 1hr after scheduled reservation to be seated. Waiter was interested in a high priced receipt, not in being a great waiter. Food = WAY to expensive....Serving Sizes = WAY to small....Drinks = Eh quality and HUGE price tag. The restaurant itself, though, is an amazing visual display, and the food was pretty good.

I've done 22 reviews so far, and have not yet given a 5-star.  In thinking about the best experience that I've had in a restaurant recently, I'd have to say Tao in Las Vegas.  The combination of the tasty foods, fun decor, and excellent service makes Tao Las Vegas deserving of my first 5-star rating!  Of course, the Vegas excitement adds to the total experience.

This isn't one of Yelpers' favorite joints to dine at in Vegas based on the ratings, so I'll share a couple of tips of what I've done and hopefully that'll be helpful to you folks out there:

- Making reservations here is a must!  Without reservations, this place is impossible to get into, unless you know people, or do the ol' slipping a bill into the handshake action.  (If you do, try $20 or higher)

- Come with friends that are ready to party, because this is a party joint!  Meet at the bar, so that if you have folks coming in from different hotels, you can enjoy the drinks while you wait.

- Once you're seated, order sharable appetizers, like the Edamame, Satay Chicken, or  Thai Stuffed Shrimps.

- If you like Sake, they have a pretty good selection of Sakes.  If you haven't tried the Nigori Sake (unfiltered), I'd suggest at least trying that.  The best way is to ask the server to give you the rundown.We had the Voice in the Mist bottle and it was yummy!

- For your entree, you MUST get Miso-Glazed Chilean Seabass!!  It's my favorite fish entree in the world!  Savory white flaky tender bits of tasty fish... oh my.  It definitely melts in your mouth yet creates a flavor explosion.  So good!  My friend likes the Wasabi Crusted Filet Mignon, but I think it's not nearly as good as the Seabass.

I've been to Tao now for 3 years.  I've had a great experience every single time.  I now cannot imagine going to Vegas without my Chilean Seabass experience at Tao.

I've been here four times and aside from a minor intoxicated mix up on bottle vs. drink service made by moi and group and small service lapse whilst sitting alone, this is dining nirvana. 

Located inside the Venetian, which already smells great, the entrance and gift shop have the wonderful smell of sandalwood. The stone "baths" greet you as you walk to the hostess station...each time I've visited they have been filled with water, rose petals and candles. I've heard mention that there may be events where Buddha nymphs are soaking in the tubs...could be urban legend, could be wishful thinking by drunken pigs. Either way, I wish I was a Tao bath girl.... 

But I digress...back to the food. Whether dining alone at the sushi bar, partying with friends, or starting at a special someone this place accommodates the mood. Dark wood, candle light, ginormous statues of the Buddha, fresh flowers, small medium and large Buddha statues abound. I have not yet had the pleasure of seeing the club - but dining here has been enough satisfaction. 

The sushi is divine and overpriced...individual order are great but if you really want to be impressed, throw your credit card to the wind and go for the "chef's special". - otherwise known as sushi roulette in Vegas. You give them an amount to spend and then wait for monster plate. The sashimi of Kobe beef (think carpaccio) is glorious, buttery, melty goodness and even better with the smokey sauce that accompanies the avocado tempura (sin on a plate). 

Peking duck eggrolls, Sea Bass meal or satay small plate, scallops...you could spend forever savoring. The sake menu is amazing and must be sampled - probably the reason I have never gotten to desert. But then again, there are great places within the Venetian to venture to for liquid desert!

If you like Asian food or sushi it's a must visit for the food and the atmosphere.  And no, the swanky couches in the front room are not for the uncool to lounge upon and think they can order drinks from - bottle service only and all that goes with it!

Tao was a great ending to our vacation in Vegas.  When we went, it was luckily not very busy.  We had a party of six and ate at a large round table which I like.  Much easier to conversate with everyone that way.  Our waiter was very helpful and informative.  We had no idea what to get and all of his suggestions were spot on!  At first I was worried that we were not going to have enough food, but since we ate family style, we order a bunch of little plates so we could sample many things.

It was so crowded upstairs on the dance floor that we decided to go down to the lounge part to find somewhere to sit and chill.  NEVER make the mistake of going to the lounge and feeling hungry right before the kitchen closes. You will regret it because it SMELLED good in the lounge, but the results were not so much.  Chef's roll = EWW, EWW, EWW and tiny for the amazing price of $16!!   I am generally against these type of Asian restaurants that are kinda fusion, but when you get hungry late, you get desperate. Our waiter was nice and was on top of it, so the star is for him.  Maybe it's better when you go for actual dinner, so don't take my review for that (although you might wanna stay away from the Chef's roll then too).

Love this place! We came here for V-Day and I thought the food was really yummy.  The service was nice and the interior looked awesome with a giant buddah in the dining area!  That place then later would turn into a night club.  Before you go into the restaurant you'll see some really beautiful rock tubs outside filled with rose petals and water.  aaah..romantic! I had a GIANT fortune cookie for dessert! :)

First time diner, long time clubber. Me and eleven other "bachelors" enjoyed an incredible time at Tao for a friends stag party.

After three glasses of wine I honestly can't remember what appetizers we had but they were the bomb-ass rap song. If you don't believe me, ask L.A. Lakers Robert Horry - he was at the table next to us saying hells yeah... or maybe, "As usual, I'll take the check." I wonder if he knew that the hot red head sitting next to him just came over to our table and advertised the strip club where she would be working later that night?

Our server Sereka was the cats meow. Not only could she handle 12 crazy men, but she helped us haze the groom. She hand picked a table of bachelorettes for us to send a comp bottle of champagne. Imagine the groom-to-be's surprise when 10 boa-clad bachelorettes came over and personally thanked him for the bubbly.

Oh, and definitely get the miso sea bass - delicious!

4.5 * stars

Tao is located in the Venetian. This place was packed on the Wednesday evening I went. It has low lighting and a lounge-like feel to it. Very trendy and popular. To start, I had the Tao-Tini. It obviously did its job since I barely remember dinner.

For dinner had:
Edamame-Always a delicious choice
Alaskan Salmon, Crab and Avocado Roll (...I think...I don't remember...)
Hong Kong XO Shrimp with Long Beans and Jasmine Rice

Now, that night was a little fuzzy, but I do remember the food being DELICIOUS! I hate green beans, so when I saw shrimp on a bed of rice, with green long beans circling my plate, I was convinced I made the wrong choice. Turns out long green beans aren't really green beans. They're just long beans.

The girls and I decided to dine here on Saturday night at 5:15pm.  Yes, we dined that early.  I called to reserve a table for nine a couple of days before we dined, so we got a choice of the 5:15pm or 10:45pm seating.  Since we had to get back to our rooms at Wynn to get ready for clubbing at XS, we opted for the 5:15pm seating.   I loved the Asian décor...muted lighting makes the restaurant appear like an elegant lounge.  Our round table was good for eating family style...and was located right in front of the huge Buddha statue.  

Dishes my friends and I tried and their star ratings (with 5 stars being the best):

* Edamame (4 stars / $7) - Edamame is edamame...what else can I say?
    
* Lobster Wontons with Shiitake Ginger Broth (4 stars / $16) - I didn't get a chance to taste this, but my friends loved it.  

* Miso Glazed Chilean Sea Bass with Wok Vegetables (5 stars / $34) - I loved this dish.  So tasty...the fish was so flaky and tender.  

* Spicy Hoi Yin Eggplant (4 stars / $9) - I kept hearing raves from my friends about this eggplant dish.    

* Mandarin Sizzled Fried Rice with Peking Duck (4 stars / $14) - My friends loved this dish, but I thought it was just ok...it could have done with more Peking duck.  As it was, the duck slices were too thin and too few.    

* Pad Thai Noodles with Shrimp (4 stars / $22) - Again, my friends raved about this dish, but I found it to be so-so.  I'm picky about Thai dishes, so I expect more.  I have to say I was surprised by the large serving of pad thai since other dishes we ordered came in small servings. 

* Giant Fortune Cookie (4 stars / $10) - This fortune cooked is filled with white & dark chocolate mousse.  So pretty to look at...and the filing provided a nice taste and texture to a regular fortune cookie.  Our server also provided nine separate fortunes with our cookie, so that was a nice touch.  

* Chocolate Raspberry Wontons (4 stars / $9) - The crisp wontons filled with raspberry filing tasted wonderful with the vanilla bean ice cream.  

The wine list had a lot of good options, but we stayed away from alcohol during dinner as we were saving our drinking for our bottle service at XS the same night.  Overall, Tao has great ambiance, good food and great service.  Our server is one of the best I have ever encountered in my years of dining.  He was very patient with our group and answered our questions with a smile.  I would definitely dine here again.

Thanks Yelpers, I am quite impressed with the consensus on Tao!  It's not NYC, but it puts its best foot or food forward.  If you read my last review on Alex I had to chastise you guys a little bit, but fret not, you have been redeemed.  After an amazing "evening with Cher" @ Caesars palace, my friend and I fell through Tao and had an extraordinary time.  Details:

Arrival was swift, I anticipated a wait based on prior Yelpers experience, and received the Olive Garden style beeper then shown to the well decorated and seductively lit lounge with quite a view of the gussied up Vegas party-goers.  

After about twenty minutes, my dining companion and I received our table with a round of drinks on the house due to the wait.  Way to go on the customer service Tao.  I had the Tao-tini--A+ my friend the Tao Cosmo.  Both smooth and easy.  

The food--ordered in portions and had wonderful dishes:
Spicy Lobster/Crab roll excellent
Steamed Veggie Dumplings--needs extra dunking sauce yum yum
Dragon Tail ribs--ok could have done without
Crispy Rice Tuna Tartar--OMG, could have 2 of these
Hot Edamame--fav.

Dessert was over the top:  
Giant Fortune Cookie exploding w/ chocolate mousse VERY rich, so be warned
Rice Pudding Creme Brule w/ extra scoop of ginger ice cream!  Just like mom used to make back south--right.  

Our waiter was helpful, but a bit stuffy--otherwise an overall stellar performance by Tao.  Be careful not to trip on the way out over the eager Tao nightclub revelers.

Tao is a chic, dim lit asian place at the Venetian. The entrance is lined up with empty bathubs filled with water and flowers. When you walk in and pass the lounge into the restaurant, a large Buddha statue welcomes you into this beautiful restaurant. I went here before catching a show & loved my food!
I ordered:
appetizer- veggie dumplings (sauteed ginger & sesame seeds)
entree- Sushi--spicy tuna, salmon, & asparagus roll. (it was amazing) 
dessert- white choc/raspberry fried wontons w/ icecream

*warning*- no free refills. 4 bucks for a glass of sprite filled with ice? eh. Anyhow, the ambiance is trendy, the service was quick, the food was delicious & overall..was a great first night out during my vegas trip this past weekend!

make sure you have reservations well in advance!

mMMmMmmMmm yummy yummy yummy yummy!!!!

their sashimi was AWESOME
they had sake also 
i had a hot pot dish that was ABSOLUTELY delicious .. i think it was thai flavored?
yummersssssssssssssss!!!!!!
everything looked greaaaaaaaaaaaaaaat!
i would definately go back..... however.. PRICEY!!!!!
even better... we get to get in a shorter line to go clubbing that night after dinner because they gave us a stamp =) .... what i mean by that is we ate at about 6 oclock.... went back to the club later on at night.. and still got in a shorter line =) and it was labor day weekend =)  yaaaaaay =P !!!!

mMm... i spent about $100 dollars on dinner that night MYSELF.. it's VEEEERY expensive.. but the food is delicious... haha.... i'd go again if i somehow won a few hundred at the tables ;) jusst kidding =P .. i'd recommend this place =)

I had a horrible experience here all due to the staff. We had 9:45 reservations at the restaurant and the morning of our reservation they called to confirm. We thought Tao was the perfect place for dinner because we heard about the great food and if you eat dinner there 

Later that evening we got to the restaurant at 9:40 to make sure we were seated promptly. A lot of us were starving because of the late dinner reservation but that was what we could get. 10:10 we stil weren't seated. I decided to go drop off something at the hotel room since we were staying in the Palazzo. Being that we had a late dinner reservation I decided to try to get a stamp to ensure that I could easily come back to the restaurant. I go to this desk near the door to ask for a stamp. The guy tells me that I need to get in line for a stamp. I look at the line and it's empty so I crawled under the rope. Immediately this security guard comes over.

Guard: Excuse me Maam, you'll need to go all the way outside to get in line. You can't line jump.

I look out at the entrance which was only a few feet from me and there's still no one in line.

Me: Umm there's no one in line.

Guard: I know that but you can't line jump. My manager won't have it and I'll be the weak link.

So begrudgingly I go outside. There's another guard at the entrance. He proceeds to tell me that it's a $20 cover to get in.

Me: What? I was just in the restaurant and they told me to come out here to get a stamp. I have dinner reservations here and just want to drop something off in my room

Guard 2: Well if you have dinner reservations you'll have to get in the reservation line to get a stamp.

Me: I was in the reservation line to check in and they didn't give us a stamp.

Guard 2: Well that's where you'll need to go

I stand in the reservation line. A guy is yelling at the hostess letting her know that he's been waiting 50 minutes for a table, and they had reservations too. The hostess wasn't giving in and the guy got angry, threw the pager at her, and yelled some obscenities.

I proceed to tell my story to the hostess and she tells me that she has to get the stamp girl to come over to give me a stamp and I have to wait. My friend Kelly comes up to the desk because we've been waiting for a while for our table. Kelly talks to the hostess.

Hostess: Oh right, you had a table for 4

Kelly: No 8. You guys called this morning to confirm

Hostess: 8? Oh... well then you'll have to come back in 5 minutes and then I can tell you what's available.

Kelly: Why can't you tell me what's available now? We had 9:45 reservations and it's 10:20 now.

Hostess: Just come back in 5 minutes and I'll let you know what's available.

kelly and I are upset but because we had a group of girls for a bacheleorette and they all wanted to go clubbing, Tao was the best option because we get dinner and the club included so we decide to proceed with dinner.

I then proceed to ask the hostess again about the stamp. She says that I need to finish my dinner before I can get stamped. UGH!

We finally get seated and eat our meal. The food isn't that great. I've gotten better at normal $5 chinese restaurants. The waiter brings Kelly brown rice instead of white. She mentions it and he says, "Don't worry I won't charge you for it." 

At the end of dinner, lo and behold we were charged for the rice. Kelly mentions it and tells the guy that he said he wouldn't charge.

Waiter: I don't remember saying that. Since you ate it we have to charge you for it

Kelly: No i mentioned it to you and you said you wouldn't. That's the reason I ate it

Waiter: Tell you what. I can hook you up. I'll get the girl to stamp you so that you can get into the club.

We are SUPPOSED TO GET INTO THE CLUB if we have dinner there!!! Never again will I go there!

My company choose to thow a party here for CES and let's just say it was a blast. How can you not have a blast when it's all you can drink? But by the end of the night we were starving. I would reccomend coming to Tao if you have a set reservation or know someone, otherwise you are going to be waiting in line for a long ass time. The place is like a maze and when you are drunk, figuring your way in and out is something else. During the club part, they have naked girls in the bathtubs which is pretty incredible. I couldn't stop staring. A great place to come if you are looking to throw down serious money for guareenteed good time. If you don't get bottle service, plan on trying to work your way into VIP or be sadly disappointed by the crowds surround the bar!!

The food is just so-so. Felt a tad overpriced, but the menu was very unique. I ordered the black peppered filet mignon with udon noodles and I enjoyed the noodles more than the steak. I asked for medium rare and it came out burnt and medium well. I believe that such a tender piece of meat cooked anything more than medium might as well be tossed out. 

I'll give props to the bartender for making some really good drinks. I felt the buzz half way through my dinner, but I couldn't taste the alky at all.

(Club reviewed in different section.)

Great atmosphere.  The interior looks really cool with it's Asian theme.  A super popular place, so it is best that you make a reservation way in advance, although the walk-in wait for us was about 20-25 minutes.  There's a lounge/bar that you can sit at while you wait for a table.  

I love their desserts.  Their food was standard in taste.  Portions are average.  However, a meal here can be quite expensive.  We came here mainly for their ambiance.  If you want awesome food at a good price, you don't really need to come to Tao.

I had a really good experience at Tao for dinner. We didn't have to wait long for our table because Larry made reservations. The atmosphere is really nice. Very intimate! We had a very nice waiter (who even gave us stamps to go to Lavo.)

I ordered a Tao-tini. Yummy! I'm not a huge fan of hot and sour soup but I did enjoy theirs. The rest of the night I had sushi which were all fresh.

Walking into a club to have dinner wasn't something on the top of my list of things to do but I heard many good things, so in I went. Red accents along a dark backdrop. A hallway full of naked women in bathtubs covered in rose petals. Winding maze to get from the hallways to the upstairs dining area. Plenty of bouncers to ensure eating privacy. All seemed fairly crazy to me at a place we were to have dinner but It was well worth it.

The Tao restaurant had some of the most delicious salmon I've ever had. I ordered the soy ginger glazed salmon with udon noodles and spinach. The salmon cooked to perfection, beautifully medium in the middle, and the udon was amazing. Every morsel, every bite, and every scent was packed full of flavor. The seasoning enhanced the flavor of the salmon rather than masking it.

I eat a lot of Asian food, not because I'm Asian myself but because there is an abundant amount of Asian restaurants in my area. I wouldn't say the food at Tao is authentic but it is a warm welcome to to the culinary world with Asian influences.

Overall, It was the best salmon I've ever had and definitely worth the price and I would definitely return. Next time I'm bringing my appetite and dancing shoes as the club is amazing.

I was pleasantly surprised!  Much less pretentious than I thought, but the waitor was a little on the pushy side.  I suppose with the economy, Vegas is hurting too so he's gotta "make it work".  Other than that, here's the rundown:

-Sushi:  We shared a few rolls for appetizers and they were good, but definitely $$ for the portion.  We had a spicy, crunchy tuna roll and something else with yellowtail; like I said, good, but I've had better at Sushi Wabi in Chicago.  

-Drinks:  Sake martini, waaaaay too heavy on the vodka.  Left a stinging sensation in my mouth and not in a good way.  The other tini's were on the sweet side.  

-Dinner:  We had peking duck for two...MUST try.  It was tender, flavorful and a great portion size.  Friends had chicken curry, nice and spicy and chilean sea bass, also delicious.  I thought the entrees were all reasonably priced, especially for Vegas.  

-Atmosphere:  Lots of typical d-bags yelling "Vegas Baby!!" and lots of typical chippees in slutty outfits (us included).  But overall, no complaints.  We were seated on time, the service was efficient (our food came out really fast!) and $110 per person (dinner for six, split 5 ways for b-day girl) seemed like a pretty good deal for as much as we ate and drank.

I've always HATED Vegas...until this last trip.  Unfortunately, Tao was the one blight on the trip.  The food was ok and the bill wasn't outrageous, which can be a typical Vegas pitfall.

We ate family-style and had a roll that I'm fairly certain is an exact rendition of fish-food., which was partly our fault for eating sushi on a Sunday.  The food came out so quickly that we didn't really have much time to enjoy our meal.  That is not to say that they were trying to turn the table over though, it took about 45 minutes to receive our bill and pay for it.

Bottom-line: the food was mostly edible and the service was alright.

Get a booth near the sushi bar as it gives you a great watching spot. They move fast to get tables seated and get you out of there unless you get a bottle of sushi or any wine. The food is good and on Thursday's apparently turns into a happening spot. The line is freaking long so to avoid that, get in at around 9:30 and get your dinner to end at 1030ish and find the hostess to stamp your hand and enter the club and get down and dirty.

I was a little shocked that the prices weren't out of control considering the hype around tao (at least in gossip magazines =P) Anyhow, they put fresh clams in the miso soup and the sushi rolls were good, considering we were not coastside. The other asian fusion looked ok too, typical pad thai and some chinese/meiguoren type dishes, ie: orange chicken...The service was really really good though, they brought our food out and while pouring a champagne toast (bachelorette party) it got cold and they made a whole new order, and also gave us complimentary watermelon kamikaze shots on the house. Niiiiice. The waiters were all young and not hard on the eyes either...heeeey.

The food was 50/50... it seemed like they had the worst kitchen possible handle the appetizers & sushi, while an average chef handled the main dishes. The place was grossly overpriced so you're really just paying for the atmosphere. My fiancee and I were extremely let down and the place did not live up to the hype. Our hostess said that our dinner ($185 mind you) guaranteed entrance to the nightclub after but, of course, incompetent doormen & nightclub managers had no idea what we were promised an hour earlier. Save your money and go somewhere else! A group of our friends who made it in the club were split up since women were the only ones allowed upstairs. My fiancee and myself, on the otherhand, refused paying to go in since dinner was terrible and their word meant close to nothing. Honestly, if you want good asian food then go to an Asian restaurant, not an asian-themed restaurant. If you want a better Vegas experience take your spouse to Bobby Flay's Mesa Grill for dinner @ Caesars and the Mix @ Mandalay (the Hotel) for after dinner lounging and drinks, where at both places you'll be deeply satisfied.

This was some of the best Asian food we've ever had. The service was outstanding and the food equal. I highly recommend the Chilean Seabass and the Shobu Shobu. Also, the giant fortune cookie dessert was excellent! It was busy but we never felt ignored and the quality of the food didn't suffer.  I'm not usually comfortable with a bathroom attendant but it' s a nice touch.

I guess for Vegas this is suppose to be good. The front of the house was horrendous. Servers were friendly but pacing of the food was so off.  The food was ok, we had sushi and sashimi, over-priced.  I think this place is highly over-rated but I guess you go  for the ambience. I don't  think I would come back but coming from the Bay Area I have high expectations.

My wife and I had dinner here with friends on Saturday night and came away a bit underwhelmed.

By no means was the food bad, it very tasty, mostly what soured my view of the establishment was the overly loud music. I realize it converts to a club at night, however not being able to hear someone across the table unless they speak loudly and I lean in does not make for an enjoyable dining experience.

I was also a bit disappointed that I was steered away from ordering the orange chicken by my waitress. I don't consider myself someone who enjoys very spicy food, and when I ordered it our waitress asked if I liked my food spicy. I explained I do like some spice, but not large amounts of it. She then told me I might be better off ordering something else. Not wanting to ruin dinner with friends by not eating my meal I opted to order the filet mignon with udon noodles. While I enjoyed the flavor of the filet with udon I was disappointed in two regards. Firstly the amount of filet mignon with the noodles was pitiful, I had maybe 3 oz of meat total in my meal I think. Secondly, the sauce with udon noodles was tossed in was pretty average, I think I've had the same sauce in a meal at Noodles & Co.  To top it off, my friend ordered the orange chicken despite our waitress' warning and found that it wasn't nearly as spicy as the waitress made it out to be.

Despite hearing how great some of the desserts here were, we decided to skip it and go elsewhere so that we could actually hold a conversation without shouting.

Is it fair for me to review a restaurant just based on the bar scene? Stopped in for a few drinks with the wife on a wed night (dead). Nice lounge feel to the front, cool music and the mood lighting created a nice relaxing atmosphere. 

Drinks were super strong; but so was the bill! $28 for two well drinks and ouch!!!

This place gets uber packed on a friday or saturday night so remember to bring your patience. Flagging down one of the bartenders can become a rather trying , and frustrating task. Oh yeah, sometimes they stick women in these bathtubs up from for a "sexy" look the club. Kind of odd, but still cool nevertheless

Over priced. Seriously, why did we even contemplate paying the bill? We did not get our moneys worth at this restaurant. Asian food is not suppose to cost $80 - $100 per person. The portions were small and the food was nothing to brag about. I was still hungry after dinner. I ,personally, would not dine here again. Not enough value for your money.

I am a very energetic yelper and try to rate as high as possible, okay so the food was amazing however our waiter lacked personality and manners, he forgot to ask us if we wanted drinks....ridiculous, then he took our order 45 minutes later we flagged him down for our food, then our food was amazing!!! however we had to keep asking other waiters to find ours...not impressed with the service at all.

pros:
- food was good
- nice ambiance
- waiter was knowledgable and pleasant
- hostess gave us free drink coupons for wait time - see below

cons:
- we had 9:45 reservations. we were staying in the hotel and called 15 mins prior to our reservation to let the hostess know we were on the way down. she told us not to be late, or they would give our table up. THEN we get there and wait 1 HOUR before being seated. wtf - how does this happen when you have a reservation. 10, maybe even 20 minutes i can deal with. but a fucking hour??!! ridiculous.
- then we get our drink coupons and give them to the cocktail waitress. she was a completed bitch. sorry if you hate your job, but its your job. its in the service industry. you're there to serve. ugh.

although i enjoyed my meal once i was seated...the waiting thing ruined it for me. its not somewhere i would choose to go back to again. maybe if they offered take out?

I have been to Tao before, though usually earlier in the evening and we liked it enough to go back. Well, that is the last time I will be going there and also the last time I will recommend that anyone else go either.
